Advanced Vocabulary - Page 10

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 10

Continue developing your advanced vocabulary with these sophisticated words essential for eloquent communication in academic and professional settings.

Navigation

This is page 10 of 12. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Mendacious

/menˈdeɪʃəs/

adjective

Given to or characterized by deception or falsehood; lying.

"The mendacious witness was caught in several contradictions."

Synonyms: dishonest, lying, deceitful

Category: Honesty

Mercurial

/mərˈkjʊriəl/

adjective

Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind.

"Her mercurial temperament made her difficult to work with."

Synonyms: volatile, unpredictable, capricious

Category: Temperament

Meticulous

/məˈtɪkjələs/

adjective

Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.

"The meticulous researcher checked every source twice."

Synonyms: careful, precise, thorough

Category: Precision

Misanthrope

/ˈmɪsənθroʊp/

noun

A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society.

"The old misanthrope lived alone and rarely spoke to neighbors."

Synonyms: recluse, hermit, cynic

Category: Personality

Mitigate

/ˈmɪtəɡeɪt/

verb

To make less severe, serious, or painful.

"The company took steps to mitigate the environmental damage."

Synonyms: alleviate, reduce, lessen

Category: Reduction

Myriad

/ˈmɪriəd/

noun, adjective

A countless or extremely great number; countless or extremely great in number.

"The garden contained a myriad of colorful flowers."

Synonyms: countless, numerous, multitude

Category: Quantity

Nascent

/ˈnæsənt/

adjective

Just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential.

"The nascent technology showed promise for future development."

Synonyms: emerging, developing, budding

Category: Beginning

Nefarious

/nəˈferiəs/

adjective

Extremely wicked or villainous; iniquitous.

"The detective uncovered the criminal's nefarious plot."

Synonyms: wicked, villainous, evil

Category: Evil

Obsequious

/əbˈsikwiəs/

adjective

Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.

"His obsequious behavior toward the boss made his colleagues uncomfortable."

Synonyms: servile, fawning, sycophantic

Category: Behavior

Obstinate

/ˈɑːbstənət/

adjective

Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action.

"Despite all evidence, he remained obstinate in his beliefs."

Synonyms: stubborn, headstrong, inflexible

Category: Stubbornness

Omniscient

/ɑːmˈnɪʃənt/

adjective

Knowing everything; having unlimited understanding or knowledge.

"The omniscient narrator knew the thoughts of all characters."

Synonyms: all-knowing, all-seeing, wise

Category: Knowledge

Onerous

/ˈoʊnərəs/

adjective

Involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.

"The onerous task of reviewing thousands of documents took months."

Synonyms: burdensome, demanding, taxing

Category: Difficulty
